posts.cooked: Google confirmed to Android Authority that it is committed to publishing Androidâ€™s source code, so this change doesnâ€™t mean that Android is becoming closed-source. The company will continue to publish the source code for new Android releases, so when Google releases Android 16 later this year, weâ€™ll get the source code for the update. In addition, Google will continue to publish the source code for Androidâ€™s Linux kernel fork, as it is licensed under GPLv2, which mandates source code releases, and is separate from AOSP.

posts.cooked:
putting pre-emptive point, assuming that android will be closed like iphone and other apple products.

then signal relies on major two closed platforms. which i think is bad, because it gives more power to closed systems. signal should have a plan to support alternate platforms, which are truly open and transparent.

only small players exist. but gnu/linux is way to go. and i also mean as a primary client.

i count android as a fake linux. too much googleâ€™s closed stuff in it. ios is abuse of freebsd by apple.

posts.cooked:
https://9to5google.com/2025/08/25/android-apps-developer-verification/

article summary: google requires developer signing for apps, even when sideloaded, this is for certified devices. this is done in a name of security and preventing scams.

practically this is yet more central control for alphabet inc. stock android will be walled garden like iphone and ipad. custom images can avoid this limitation, but life may become more difficult for custom images. i heard that limitation does not affect sideloading by adb.

link_counts.title: Google will require developer verification to install Android apps

posts.cooked:
zetabeta:

article summary: google requires developer signing for apps, even when sideloaded, this is for certified devices. this is done in a name of security and preventing scams.

This is likely to be used in the future to ban developers that distribute encrypted messaging apps when those will be required to be backdoored in major democracies.
